awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Curriculum to Broaden Participation in Cybersecurity for Middle School Teachers and Students (CyberMiSTS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Curriculum to Broaden Participation in Cybersecurity for Middle School Teachers and Students (CyberMiSTS) project will develop and pilot summer workshops that provide middle school Career and Technical Education (CTE) teachers with the knowledge, skills, and tools they need to actively engage their students and expose them to cybersecurity concepts and careers.  Bringing in cybersecurity expertise from a variety of sources, the CyberMiSTS curriculum will be accessible to middle school students and teachers because it will emphasize the important role of humans in cybersecurity.  Teachers will learn from cybersecurity researchers, engage in hands-on activities, and customize cybersecurity course materials for their own classrooms.   The CyberMiSTS curriculum will focus on key concepts and big questions to encourage participation from a broad and diverse set of students. 

Using a design research methodology to develop the training approach, with teachers from the first cohort sharing their experiences and mentoring a second cohort, the project team will study what CTE teachers need to be successful teaching cybersecurity in a middle school classroom.  The project builds on lessons learned from a previous SaTC EDU project by incorporating Comic-BEE, a novel online system for creating educational, branching web comics. Branching stories provide opportunities to explore cause and effect. The comic style is engaging to middle school students who are disinclined to read long texts, and can incorporate culturally relevant pedagogy with the potential to reach more students. After the summer workshop, teachers will the materials in their classrooms, and measure student learning and interest in cybersecurity careers with instruments provided by the project team.  In the future, workshop materials and curriculum will be offered as an online continuing education course.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cybersecurity, a relatively new field, needs input from a broad and diverse group of professionals as the field rapidly grows and evolves. To attract young people to the profession, research has shown that it is best to reach down to students in middle school. Yet few middle school teachers know anything about cybersecurity. And many teachers have the misconception that cybersecurity only needs people who are good at math and science. Because of this, we are losing opportunities to grow the pipeline of future workers that are critical to both our national security and our economic competitiveness in the USA.

Curriculum to Broaden Participation in Cybersecurity for Middle School Teachers and Students (CyberMiSTS) was designed to address the problem of not having middle school teachers prepared to teach cybersecurity. A curriculum was developed, and materials gathered, for a summer workshop for teacher professional development. Rather than diving deeply into the underlying math and science, or requiring a computer lab in the classroom, the CyberMiSTS workshop focused on key concepts (Data Protection, Web Security and Privacy) and big questions (What information should be protected? How can online information be protected? What can I do to protect my information?) that could be addressed by any teacher, in any classroom. The workshop also emphasized cybersecurity careers: what jobs need doing, and what skills and preparation are required to do them. The CyberMiSTS team wants teachers and students to understand that not all cybersecurity jobs require computer coding, and some jobs don't even require a college degree.

The workshop was delivered twice. The first workshop was held face-to-face over two weeks at Stony Brook University, with lectures delivered by cybersecurity researchers/professors. The Stony Brook and Secure Decisions PIs were on hand to lead discussions, guide online activities, and answer questions. They also guided the participants through the process of creating branching interactive graphic stories about cybersecurity scenarios using Copmic-BEE, an online tool created at Secure Decisions. The second workshop was held online over three weeks (with shorter days) using Zoom, with the same content and activities. Participants included both novice and experienced teachers who taught a range of subjects in school districts representing very diverse student bodies. Each workshop was followed by a half-day symposium where the teachers reported and reflected on their experience teaching cybersecurity units in their classes.

Data collected during the workshop revealed that the teachers' understanding of cybersecurity concepts and careers, and confidence in their ability to teach it to their students, both increased during the workshop. Data collected at the symposia revealed that, in general, their confidence increased even more after teaching a unit on cybersecurity to their students. Anonymous and aggregated student data was also shared, helping to identify classroom approaches that are effective in sparking interest in cybersecurity. In one class, after researching cybersecurity work roles, 22% of responses by students indicated that the student would consider pursuing specific cybersecurity work roles.

Overall, the CyberMiSTS project has identified an evidence-based approach for teacher professional development that enables middle school teachers to rapidly develop familiarity and confidence with foundational cybersecurity curriculum. Based on this work, the graduate student supported by CyberMiSTS is currently developing a model for teacher professional development that shows how this approach may be applied to other technological areas that teachers need to come up to speed on quickly.
